High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz3p0U4uQ4M

The short 56-year-old had a receding hairline and a neat goatee beard. He wore a black suit, a red tie and rectangular spectacles. He goes by at least seven names and keeps a lower profile than the Chinese dignitaries who have visited African capitals to trumpet Beijing’s burgeoning alliance with a continent whose oil and minerals have helped feed China’s phenomenal economic growth. Most commonly, he is known as Sam Pa.

11:07 am
BE

Summary: Despite weak IP and FAI numbers, Q3 GDP growth slowed only
moderately (6.9% yoy, consensus 6.8%). Meanwhile, strengthened leading
indicators suggest a possible investment-led growth rebound in Q4. In
particular, floor space started picked up (Sep: +15.3% yoy; Aug: -16.7%; Jul: -
21.3%), and fiscal situation improved.
GDP growth of Q3 came out today at 6.9% yoy (7.0% yoy in H1), higher than
the market expectation of 6.8% yoy (Figure 1). The stronger-than-anticipated
growth was driven by the primary sector (4.1% yoy in Q3, vs. 3.5% in H1) and
the tertiary sector (8.6% yoy in Q3, vs. 8.3% in H1).

BE

Growth of secondary industries (including mining, manufacturing and
construction), however, slowed down from 6.1% yoy in H1 to 5.8% in Q3. This
is also reflected by weak activity indicators such IP and FAI (Figure 2). Average
yoy growth of IP in Q3 was only 5.9%, much lower than the 6.3% in H1 and
8.0% in 2014Q3. Similarly, FAI growth for Jan-Sep was only 10.3%, more than
1 percentage point lower than the 11.4% ytd growth at end-June.
On the other hand, some leading indicators seem to suggest that there will
likely be an investment rebound in Q4. Most notable development include: (i) a
strong pickup in floor space starts on the property market, and (ii) an
improvement of the fiscal situation. Both are consistent with our earlier
projection that strong recovery of land sales since July signals a soon-to-come
rebound in property investment and will bring the fiscal slide in 2015H1 to its
end (see our report: The end of China’s fiscal slide on October 8).
On property market, floor space starts strengthened in September (Figure 3).
The ytd decline narrowed to –12.6% from –16.8% in both July and August.
Translated into monthly numbers, it actually implies a +15.3% yoy growth in
September, as against -16.7% and -21.3% in August and July, respectively.
Government revenues improved on the back of land sales recovery. Local
government land sales revenues declined only 27.2% yoy in Q3, better than the
-36% in Q1 and -41% in Q2. As a result, general government revenues dropped
only 0.5% yoy in Q3, also better than the -3.6% in 2015H1. On expenditure
side, the acceleration seen in July and August continued: general government
budgetary spending increased 25.8% yoy in Q3 (7.8% in Q1 and 14.9% in Q2),
while general government total expenditure, including both the budget and
government funds, grew 15.8% in Q3 (-0.2% in Q1 and 6.2% in Q2).
Finally, lower CPI inflation in September (1.6%, vs. 2.0% in August) allows
more room for monetary easing, should growth in Q4 remains weak (Figure 4).
Meanwhile, strong new RMB loans (1.05 tri, vs. 0.9 tri expected) and new total
social financing (RMB1.3 tri, vs. RMB1.2 tri expected) of September, are also
indicating a possible recovery of investment in Q4.
We reiterate our view that GDP growth will pick up modestly in Q4 to 7.2% yoy
(from 7.0% in Q2 and 6.9% in Q3), led by an investment recovery. On policy
outlook, we expect no more interest rate cut until the end of 2016, but one
RRR cut for 2015Q4 and each quarter of 2016. We believe the USDCNY rate
(market closing) will remain stable at around 6.4 in the rest of 2015 and have a
moderate depreciation to 6.7 by end-2016.

BE

Which is comprehensive, I feel. Anything to add?

11:08 am

11:09 am
PM

Capital economics

PM

The continued stability of the official GDP figures will further cement concerns over their credibility. For our part, while we do think the official figures are currently overstating growth by a wide margin, we nonetheless have reason to think that actual growth was indeed broadly stable last quarter.

GDP growth slowed to 6.9% y/y in Q3, down from 7.0% y/y in both Q1 and Q2. This was slightly stronger than expected (both the Bloomberg median and our forecast were 6.8%). In seasonally adjusted q/q terms, growth edged up from 1.7% in Q2 to 1.8% last quarter.

Unfortunately, these figures need to be taken with a grain of salt as official GDP growth appears to have become a poor gauge of the performance of China’s economy. Flaws with how the GDP deflator is calculated, along with political pressure to meet growth targets that have become increasingly at risk, have meant that official growth rates have not slowed nearly as quickly as most third party measures of growth in recent years. (See last Friday’s Update, “Official GDP data set to remain political tool”, for more on the problems with the GDP data.) In particular, our China Activity Proxy (CAP) suggests that a drop-off in fiscal spending due to new budget rules caused growth to slow sharply from around 5.5% y/y in Q4 2014 to around 4.0% y/y in the first quarter of this year. In contrast, the official figures registered only a very modest deceleration from 7.2% y/y to 7.0%.

PM

That said, while the pace of growth is clearly exaggerated on the official figures, we do have reason to believe that growth was broadly stable between Q2 and Q3. After slowing sharply at the start of the year, our CAP has also stabilised on the back of policy support in recent quarters and points to growth of around 4.5% y/y in both Q2 and Q3.

Looking ahead, we think it makes sense to focus on the monthly activity data for September in order to gauge the economy’s current momentum. The data were somewhat disappointing, with industrial output growth edging down from 6.1% y/y to 5.7%. (Bloomberg 6.0%; CE 5.9%.) Meanwhile, fixed investment rose only 10.3% during the first 9 months of this year. (Bloomberg 10.8%; CE 10.7%.) Assuming that no revisions were made to previous months’ data, our calculations suggest this implies that fixed investment growth fell from 9.2% y/y in August to 6.8% in September. That said, the weakness partly reflects a stronger base for comparison – growth in both industrial output and fixed investment appear to have held up better in seasonally adjusted m/m terms. There was also some more positive news from retail sales growth which edged up from 10.8% y/y to 10.9% in nominal terms (Bloomberg 10.8%; CE 10.8%) and from 10.4% y/y to 10.8% in real terms.

Overall, today’s data suggest that while the official GDP figures continue to overstate the actual pace of growth in China by a significant margin, underlying conditions are subdued but stable. Looking ahead, our view continues to be that stronger fiscal spending and more rapid credit growth will limit the downside risks to growth over the coming quarters.

BE

Eurozone specifically.

PM

Go on then

BE

We are bullish on equities into year-end on stabilization in China/EM sentiment, as well
as supportive Q4 seasonals and technicals. Within this, we do not think the US can lead.
Our concern is over US profit margins. The NFIB survey shows that the gap between
corporate pricing and wages has turned negative for the first time since ’09. Topline
delivery has stalled and credit remains weak. US internals are challenged, with the
rollover in healthcare, and the inability of Financials to take over the leadership given
lower probability of Fed hikes. The silver lining here is that Fed inaction reinforces our
recent upgrade of commodities, both Energy and Mining, from 14th Sept. This should
help Eurozone more than the US, given larger EM exposure. Potential style rotation to
Value also benefits Eurozone more. Eurozone small caps are showing a big, 12% in USD
terms, outperformance vs US small caps – a good sign. This is the first year since ’08
where Eurozone earnings are outperforming US earnings. Look for Eurozone equities to
rebound vs the US.

11:12 am
BE

Mislav Matejka, of course.

BE

And the full note's more interesting than that one par suggests.

BE

Reading the detail, it's not so much a "buy Eurozone" as "sell US"

11:13 am
BE

We do not think so. We believe OW US in a global portfolio will work only if
equities take another leg lower. US equities continue to face a range of
headwinds, constraining their upside, in our view.
 New evidence is popping up with respect to one of our key concerns, namely
the profit margins outlook. Corporate pricing is decidedly weak – as evidenced
in poor ISM prices paid index. Also, the small companies – NFIB – survey
shows that the gap between corporate pricing and the wages has turned
negative, for the first time since ’09

BE

Topline delivery has also stalled, with ISM at breakeven levels, and could
potentially move even lower. The gap between HY credit spreads and the
S&P500 remains wide. Buybacks are at 50% of EBIT, exactly where they were
in 2007 at peak.
 US internal market leadership is challenged. Healthcare, a darling of
consensus, has recently stalled. The problem is that Financials will not be able to
take over the leadership if the Fed is unable to start hiking rates.
 The silver lining here is that the dramatic rollover in the likelihood of Fed hikes
reinforces our recent upgrade of commodities, both Energy and Mining,
from September 14th. At regional level, this should help Eurozone more than the
US, given that Eurozone is more EM leveraged, at 23% of sales vs 10% for US.

BE

Another important consideration is the potential rotation in the style leadership,
away from Growth and toward the Value style. Value has performed better than
Growth most recently, and the chart at the bottom suggests that the style
rotation has implications for regional allocation. Europe benefits from Value,
US from Growth. Furthermore, Eurozone small caps are strongly
outperforming US small caps this year, by 12% in USD. This is a good sign.
 Statistics show that US equities tended to outperform mainly in the down
markets, but this is not the direction we expect into year end. We are
constructive, but unlike the consensus, we do not believe that the main risk to
the bullish view resides with EM/China anymore, partly given the extreme
consensus nature of this worry. Our concern is with the US – see our reports
“Stay UW US” and last November’s downgrade of US.
 Fundamentally, this will be the first year since 2008 where Eurozone
earnings are going to handsomely beat US earnings, with or without
commodities. We think there is more to go on this front. Finally, the policy
differential between the two regions, as expressed in the likely forward path of
the central banks' balance sheets as a share of GDP, is clear. Look for
Eurozone to rebound vs the US.

11:18 am
PM

Want a metals week wrap?

PM

I have one from Macquarie

BE

Sure. Why not.

11:19 am
PM

LME Week 2015, what did we hear?
 We round up the news and sentiment of the week, with a notable shift to a more cautiously
constructive tone for some (copper, zinc, lead) in the wake of mine closures, while bearishness
remains for aluminium and nickel.
 Glencore ignites a price rocket: The big news came ahead of the week of course, with
Glencore’s snap announcement on the preceding Friday of wide-ranging zinc mine cutbacks, set
to take ~500ktpa of contained zinc and ~100kt of lead from the market over the balance of 2015
and most of 2016. This follows their announced 400ktpa of copper mine and smelter cutbacks in
Africa on 7 September. Sounding the reactions to both during the week, it seemed that the scale
of cuts surprised many and contributed to a more constructive view on the metals affected, though
there was some discussion around whether cuts will actually take place or how soon the mines
might come back onstream. With redundancy notices having been sent out, we are convinced
that the cuts are real, and maintain the view that the mines will be out for around a year in the
case of zinc and ~15-18 months in the case of copper.

PM

Sorry for formatting

PM

No nickel cuts expected: During the week there has been a lot of discussion about whether
Glencore would extend production cuts to nickel. Speculation has centred on Glencore’s
45,000tpa Murrin Murrin operation in Australia. We think that this is unlikely and would note
that on October 3, Glencore’s head of nickel operations, Peter Johnson, was quoted in the
Australian press as saying that Murrin Murrin was “not in the firing line” and that “curtailment
or closure is not in our lexicon”. Additionally, the miner/trader is the world’s third largest
copper miner and the largest zinc miner, with 7% and 9% of mine market share respectively
(on a strict equity basis) in 2015 (including the cuts), providing them with the capacity to
actually change the shape of the market through closures. In nickel, Glencore is a smaller
player with around 5%

11:19 am
PM

Producer hedging capping gains: After the zinc announcement there was a strong rally,
with zinc gaining 11% at one point intraday to close above $1,800/t once again, lead up 6%,
and a broad contagion rally across the complex pulling all the other base up too. Prices
softened a little during the actual week, however, and we note that ceilings began to form
amid a bout of producer hedging. Copper in particular struggled at ~$5,350/t, and we met
miners who reported hedging their forthcoming units or attempting to do so at around these
levels. While this phenomenon is less constructive, we note that the hedging takes place out
of a real sense of fear over mine economics. We spoke to several miners that admit to
viability concerns with copper prices around $4,800-5,000/t, and mixed impressions on zinc
where some would be comfortable as low as $1,400/t, while others are in the process of
reviewing operations and potentially preparing to cut.

PM

Macquarie continues to see more copper cuts coming in if prices drift back to $5,000/t or
lower for an extended period, particularly in the USA, China and the African copperbelt. With
zinc we cast a beady glance at certain Peruvian operations, and note the potential for further
cutbacks in China due to a combination of environmental controls and prices.

PM

Physical signals pointing to lower China copper smelter production?: Copper
concentrate TCRCs have moved up sharply in recent weeks, with anecdotal tales of a spot
deal between a miner and a trader at three digits (upward movements denoting market
softness). The shift has been due to a combination of China’s smelters pulling back from the
spot market in order to support their benchmark aims for the coming annual term contract
negotiations, and apparent stabilising in the output levels of complex (particularly arsenicrich)
concentrates, reducing the call for clean tonnes. This has softened expectations for the
TCRC benchmark, with most miners and smelters expecting a number either side of (but
close to) $100/t and 10c/lb. With leading miner Freeport McMoran having issued punchy
mine output guidance for next year, particularly for Grasberg, we think it is more likely to see
the benchmark settling a little above $100/t and 10c/lb (but still down from 2015’s $107/t &
10.7c/lb).

11:20 am
PM

Meanwhile as Figure 3 highlights, cathode premiums have softened only slightly since the big
move up above $100/t precipitated by the arbitrage window opening. (Ahead of LME Week
Aurubis and Codelco announced $92/t premiums to their European customers for 2016, but the
Asian premiums have yet to be arranged.) When we consider the firmness of cathode premiums in
Shanghai, continued draws on LME warehouse tonnes, and the extremely strong copper import
number for September, it rather looks as though the Chinese smelters have reduced output. The
preliminary import data showed 460kt wrought and unwrought copper, which implies a final
cathode import number of ~350kt, versus ~260kt in the three prior months. When we consider that
the bonded stocks drew by ~100kt that month also, we get the impression of a huge pull for
material into domestic China. We did not hear of any SRB activity but note that SHFE stocks have
begun to tick upwards (+17kt in the last couple of weeks), but the volumes don’t account for the
apparent inflow. Consumer restocking after the arb opened, and weaker smelter activity may be
the key.
 Zinc TCs to fall: Obviously zinc TCs should now come under pressure due to market
tightness driven by Glencore’s mine cuts. It was too early in LME Week to tell how aggressive
this may be, given some dispute about the cuts even emerging, but the compression is likely
to come soon, given Century is set to make its final shipment of concentrate next month. Of
course as we noted at the time, the annual contract TC negotiations have been thrown wide
open, with hopes amongst miners of lower terms having turned to confidence, but less clarity
on the basis price to be used. This year’s was $2,000/t (with a de-escalator or 3.3% below
$2,000/t and an up escalator of 9%) and recent price performance had delivered thoughts of
a cut to the basis, but since the Glencore announcement and associated price gains there is
less certainty. We think, on the balance of today’s information, that 2016 TCs may settle
around $220/t or $225/t, with a rollover of other terms except potentially an increase in the
de-escalator on miners’ concerns over prices.

PM

Two more blocks (sorry)

PM

Nickel gloom: Meanwhile, the main event in nickel was really the reflection of how far (down) we
have come in terms of prices since last year, when optimism still hung in the air. From the most
favoured metal in last year’s Base Metals Seminar survey, nickel has become a gloomy subject,
with much unfavourable comparison with the supply cuts seen in copper and zinc, which are
conspicuously absent for nickel excepting a certain amount of NPI pullback. Although import data
looks stronger and the open arb pulled some metal towards China, the nickel story remains
sluggish on high stocks and weak demand. That said, given the scale of the move down, fewer
players are short from here, with many funds reluctant to take a position.
 Aluminium simply the bear: Aluminium too is viewed very bearishly, and as with nickel the lack
of supply cuts has acted against sentiment. An announcement on Monday by Chinalco that it
plans to cut its Liancheng 550ktpa smelter caused barely a ripple, with those who bothered to
mention it unconvinced that the cut would actually take place. We take the view that it is likely to
have been announced in order to put pressure on the local authorities to obtain a power price cut
for next year. With a lack of cuts elsewhere, and in fact a recent rollback at Hawesville where two
potlines are now to be kept open, the metal was thus the most bearishly viewed, with a majority
picking this at our seminar as the favourite short.

11:20 am
PM

Lead and tin: The smaller metals were less discussed, though some love for lead was expressed
by a couple of parties on the back of the Glencore cuts, while tin was noted for its stickiness
around $15,000/t but was hardly the talk of the town (as usual). The Glencore cuts (plus Century
and Lisheen) are simply less impactful for lead due to over half of supply coming from scrap
batteries. That said, tightness in Chinese mine supply is becoming an issue, with the arb window
opening wide to pull in material, despite anecdotal talk of lead smelters finding it extra difficult to
obtain LCs from local banks to import concentrates. We think the latter development is likely to be
political in many cases, and reflective of the atmosphere for lead in China after a number of
pollution and safety scandals. Meanwhile the battery side of the market is said to be relatively
balanced in North America, but remains tight in Europe, though on high secondary capacity rather
than especially strong demand.
 Traders rattle some nerves: As a final thought, a recurring conversation we had during LME
Week regarded the once mighty physical trading companies, and their more recent air of
vulnerability aftershock share sell-offs for a couple, and worries over the impact of the crunch in
aluminium premiums for one or two. We were frequently asked about credit lines, counterparty risk
and the potential for withdrawals to occur, and/or the risk of a contagion if one major house was to
get into substantial credit difficulties. This scenario remains a risk in the market but in our view
currently is seen as minor, given the long-dated structuring of working capital credit lines for
merchants, and the stabilisation or even gains in many physical market terms more recently. That
said, the cutback activities of Glencore display a sense of genuine alarm at current price levels,
and strong motivation to address it.

PM

Done

BE

Have to say, from a distance, LME week looked awful. Like a throwback to a different age.

11:26 am
BE

Anyway! CS.

BE

Event: Since the equity placing the shares have made a 130% roundtrip
reflecting three main uncertainties: 1) impact of weaker demand and a
weaker credit profile on marketing earnings and business structure; 2)
liquidity and net debt levels; 3) industrial earnings. We think concerns that
marketing is facing an imminent and precipitous fall in earnings are overdone and the debt pile is manageable assuming the company executes on
the debt reduction plan (to sub $20bn) quicker than the end 2016 target - is
$4-5bn in asset sales out of $86bn in fixed assets achievable? The
divestment strategy and gearing in the business create risks but we think the
valuation upside is a sufficient offset and we reiterate our £1.75 target price

BE

Marketing: As we discuss within, we think the marketing debt structure
makes sense given the short duration of the trading assets and limited fixed
assets. The real issue is excessive levels of debt on the industrial business
and this is what the company must address. Our base case assumes the
company retains its credit rating and our marketing equity valuation is $27bn.
Predicting the impact from a downgrade to sub investment grade is difficult
but the business would likely see more stringent counterparty terms,
reduced volumes and higher funding costs. However, the group’s liquidity
position and sourcing of volumes from own mines provides an underpin. Our
downside marketing equity valuation is $16bn (implied 2015 PE of 8x).

11:27 am
BE

Valuation: we update earnings to reflect the recent zinc suspensions.
2016E cash earnings multiple is c8x (FCF yield 12%) compared to peers on
15-20x. Placing the industrial business on a below average 6x EV/EBITDA
the implied marketing valuation is c$15.5, in line with our downside valuation.

PM

11:37 am
BE

• Bottom Line: Friday evening, SHPG announced receipt of a CRL
(complete response letter) for lifitegrast for treatment of dry eye disease
(DED). The implications of the delay are threefold: (1) an approval action
date is now pushed out ~9-months, to 3Q'16 from prior Oct. 27; (2)
the recently completed OPUS-3 trial, set to read out before year-end,
introduces greater risk to the lifitegrast story. We believe the outcome
of OPUS-3 is mainly a label risk but there is also a low risk (est. 25%)
that a failed OPUS-3 trial could negatively impact approval; (3) lifitegrast
PDUFA was SHPG's primary near-term catalyst, meaning any revised
offer to buy BXLT (NR) would need to include more SHPG equity with
at least a 20% markdown vs. the original offer. We remain MP & we're
lowering out PT to $220 based on sector multiple re-rating

BE

• CRL adds ~9 months to review timeline. According to SHPG, the
reasons for the CRL were based on FDA requests for: (1) information
related to product quality; (2) additional clinical data. In issuing a CRL, we
believe the FDA was primarily concerned with reviewing the OPUS-3 data
before making an approval/label decision. According to SHPG, the FDA
did not request anything unusual as it relates to product quality. SHPG
plans to submit all of its additional data in 1Q'16, and we'd expect a 6-
month class 2 review since an efficacy supplement is involved.

BE

• CRL also introduces some label risk for lifitegrast. Recall, DED is
an indication that the FDA wants to see drugs demonstrate a benefit on
co-primary endpoint of objective signs and subjective patient-reported
symptoms. However, lifitegrast was only able to replicate improvement of
objective DED signs in Ph. 2 & 3, and the OPUS-3 was agreed upon (with
FDA) in order to determine whether lifitegrast could replicate symptom
improvement. Looking back, AGN's (OP) Restasis was approved in
2003 based on only an improvement of DED signs (Schirmer wetting
test), and it is unclear whether the FDA will grant lifitegrast the same
regulatory latitude. In our view, it is more likely lifitegrast could ultimately
get approved just on improvement in DED signs since: (1) Restasis
precedent; (2) FDA's decision to designate lifitegrast for priority review
after completion of OPUS-1/2, which suggests to us a more flexible
approach. However, we cannot completely rule out the risk that a failed
OPUS-3 trial would put approval at risk

11:38 am
BE

• Lifitegrast update changes BXLT approach. On 8/4, SHPG
announced an unsolicited bid for BXLT at a $34B transaction value. Per
the terms of the offer, each BXLT shareholder would receive 0.1687 Shire
ADR, which valued BXLT shares at ~$45.23. Based on SHPG's price
at Friday close, the offer for BXLT is currently $35.36, or 22% below the
prior offer. While we would expect SHPG to move forward with a revised
bid, we believe an increased offer would likely require more equity and/
or addition of cash, although SHPG's ability to offer cash less than 1 yr post BXLT
spin falls into a legal grey area

BE

BE

Over the last couple months it had become widely expected that the FDA would
likely require the results from Shire's third Phase III Lifitegrast study, OPUS-3, before
rendering a decision. And with the receipt of a Complete Response Letter this is what
has occurred. Importantly, it appears that top-line results from OPUS-3 should be
available in the next 6-8 weeks, which we believe will de-risk the program and allow
for an approval by mid-year 2016 (assuming a Q1:2016 refiling and 3-6 month review).
We will discuss the reasons behind our conviction in OPUS-3 and the eventual
approval in the following pages. But first we wanted to reiterate our SHPG thesis, and
our belief that investors should be adding right now, even ahead of what we believe
will be a positive OPUS-3 outcome.

Please note they say this every other week.

BE

First, note that Shire's current portfolio – without Baxalta or Lifitegrast – remains
compelling, with good duration throughout the franchises and the ability to leverage
its balance sheet up to $12-14B to acquire complementary, durable orphan growth
assets. From a standalone perspective, assuming a fully leveraged share buyback as
a proxy for capital deployment, Shire is currently is trading at 12-13x adjusted 2016
earnings, 10-11x adjusted 2017 earnings, and 8-9x adjusted 2018 earnings. Either via
a share repurchase, or proper capital deployment into high quality orphan assets, we
believe that the valuation is relatively well protected right at these levels (and again,
we make this statement with or without Baxalta, and with or without Lifitegrast). And
if Shire is able to report positive OPUS-3 and derisk Lifitegrast, we believe that the
Street will begin to reward the shares, which would likely allow for management to
once again "re-pitch" their rationale behind the proposed Shire/Baxalta combination,
which we believe could set the stage for even more meaningful transformation of
the growth story. For perspective, if Shire were able to secure Baxalta around the
terms that have been proposed, the SHPG/BLXT entity would be trading at 11-12x
the 2017 pro forma earnings, and 9-10x the 2018 pro forma earnings, which is in
line with Valeant's current 2017/2018 multiples, and a fairly significant discount to
Allergan's 2017/2018 multiples. And importantly, this SHPG/BXLT pro forma entity
would also be in a position to lever its balance sheet to roughly $25-30B, to acquire
durable orphan growth assets. Applying that potential leverage to a share repurchase
instead of growth assets as a proxy for capital deployment, the proforma SHPG/BXLT
would be trading closer to 6-7x adjusted 2018 earnings. That type of valuation, for this
type of entity, would be very compelling.

BE

To state as clearly as possible, this would be
one of the highest quality organic/inorganic hybrid models in the space, trading at
blended 2017/2018 multiples that are similar to Valeant (and below Allergan), but with
little-to-no leverage and in a more advantaged position to purchase very high-quality orphan assets.

11:41 am
BE

Additionally, Shire currently has four Phase III programs, six Phase II
programs and thirteen Phase I/pre-clinical programs and invests roughly 14-15% of
revenues into R&D, versus roughly 3-4% for Valeant (and roughly 7-8% for Allergan).
And if SHPG shareholders still do not want a proforma SHPG/BXLT combination, we
believe that the message sent to management will be that they are willing for Shire to
move directly to purchasing orphan assets now, and do not feel that the accretion via
Baxalta and the potential expanded balance sheet are necessary given the perceived
Baxalta/hemophilia duration risk. In that instance, we believe SHPG shares would also
trade higher on a Baxalta transaction break. Again, if there is perceived value in the
Valeant model, then Shire – either standalone or via the combination with Baxalta –
provides both likely better organic growth (given our conviction in Lifitegrast and the
pipeline) with a cleaner balance sheet that will allow for more thoughtful and valuecreating business development at multiples that are similar to VRX, while remaining
an innovative company with likely additional internal pipeline generation. At the
current valuation, this hybrid model looks like one of the most compelling in our space
and we would use any weakness around the Lifitegrast CRL to initiate positions today

PM

It has been a rough ride for metal and mining giant BHP Billiton. Revenues have come under persistent pressure due to weakening commodity prices. Despite one of the strongest balance sheets in the sector, promises made to shareholders have proven tough to keep.

PM

With these commitments in mind the company turned to a nervous bond market earlier this week for some $6.44bn equivalent of hybrid debt funding as outlined below.

11:44 am
PM

Back in May 2015 BHP spun off certain assets into a new business – South32 – whilst assuring investors it would be able to maintain the company’s dividend in line with its policy to ‘steadily increase or at least maintain the dividend per share.’ At current prices and despite a significant cost cutting exercise, the company will be free cash flow negative to the tune of -$2.5bn after maintaining said dividend. With little sign of a near term recovery in commodity prices and a commitment to a solid single A rating, it would seem management have somewhat backed themselves into a corner. A sceptical equity market has watched the implied dividend yield climb significantly through 2014 and 2015 to an elevated 10% area today.

PM

Locking in a blended cost of hybrid debt funding at 6% for a minimum of five years, primarily to maintain the dividend in the face of commodity weakness, may well prove to be a costly error. With an interest bill set to rise by $160m per annum (before tax shield savings), perhaps a near term cut to the dividend would have been a more appropriate response which frankly is already discounted by the market.. Companies often pay special dividends when times are good and turn to bond markets when times are tough. The reason is that reducing the dividend can be a costly exercise for existing equity owners which is a short-sighted strategy in my opinion. Cyclical companies – like BHP – should leave themselves scope to respond to both cyclical downturns as well as upturns. No one can tame the commodities cycle.

BE

UTV announced this morning the sale of its TV assets to ITV for £100m in cash. We see the deal as a strategic plus, especially if ITV can charge retransmission fees for the main channel where we expect more newsflow before Christmas. Reiterate as top pick in the media sector.

BE

ITV will pay a casH consideration of £100m for the TV assets of UTV i.e. The ITV1 franchise in Northern Ireland and UTV Ireland, which operates a channel in the Republic of Ireland. Post completion of the deal ITV will own 13 of the 15 regional licenses of the Channel 3 network. This move has been widely anticipated.

BE

Possible short term impact on optics of ITV but, strategically, makes sense

UTV's TV assets (particularly in the RoI) had a relatively poor 1H, with Northern Ireland TV ad revenues down 2% and a disappointing launch of UTV Ireland. However, it makes sense strategically in cleaning up the ITV1 network and reducing leakage if retransmission revenues are introduced. It also suggests ITV management is more confident on the overall TV secular position i.e. It is increasing its exposure to TV.

UTV acquisition helps upside from retransmission fees

Northern Ireland has a higher pay-Tv penetration than the UK as a whole (71pc vs 62pc according to Ofcom's current Communications Market report), primarily because of higher Sky penetration. By acquiring UTV's TV assets it would therefore increase its overall share of retransmission revenues for ITV1 if the government approves the introduction of retrans fees for the main channels (we estimate an extra £6-7m of 100pc margin revenues). We expect the government to announce its thinking on retransmission revenues before Christmas and ITV's move may suggest it is feeling confident about the outcome.

BE

Tribal issued a profit warning indicating profits for the year are now expected to be significantly below previous expectations. We have reduced our EBIT forecasts by 48%/43%/39% for the year to Dec15/16/17 as we assume the 6-13% reduction in our revenue forecasts are largely to do with margin-rich licence revenues. Extending customer programme timelines, not enough medium-sized and smaller opportunities due to historic focus on larger contracts and increasing competition are all contributory factors. Key to rebuilding investor confidence is the appointment of a new CEO and this process is said to be advancing well. We believe one of his or her key priorities should be on sharpening the group’s focus – product, target geographies, go-to-market etc. and to then ensure it has the optimal cost structure to support this strategy. Tribal has significant IP and a valuable installed base; it now needs to match much stronger operational execution to drive shareholder returns.

12:02 pm
BE

First, we believe competitors are more creatively marketing cloud-based solutions while Tribal has not fully prepared its cloud-based solution (Sky Software) for the UK North American markets. Tribal has recently seen a few tenders go to competitors and their partners. While no vendors have a fully formed cloud-based offering, large and medium sized ERP competitors are partnering with smaller vendors to market SaaS-like solutions to universities. While Tribal's Sky Software's core platform is cloud-based, not all functions, particularly country-specific features, are available. We believe development and sales resources have been diverted away from Sky Software and its cloud-based solution due to Tribal's focus on delivering its large on-premise software (SITS) projects. While we believe Tribal will need more than an few quarters to launch a fully-functional cloud-based solution for the UK and North American market, we do not believe competitors' individual products are significantly more advanced, but are being better marketed with services and technology partners. As a result, we believe Tribal is still well positioned to remain with its existing customers for any potential migrations to cloud-based solutions.

Second, a few of Tribal's larger customers have delayed their planned implementations of extra functions. The delays have led to both deferred software sales and lower margin services.

Third, Tribal's pipeline of small and medium sized deals have not progressed successfully due to the sales focus on winning large deals. Tribal is making changes to its marketing and sales leadership. Moreover, the company expects to appoint a new CEO shortly, which should help address the above issues.

BE

The competitive outlook, customer delays and sales execution issues, we lower our 2015 EBIT by 55% to £7.7m from £17.1m and our 2016 EBIT by 41% to £11.3m from £19.0m. Tribal is planning cost reductions that should benefit 2016 more than 2015.

The company should remain within its 3.0x EBITDA debt covenant. We estimate net debt of £23.4m at the end of 2015, 1.8x EBITDA of £13.2m. We expect shares to drop significantly on the back of today's trading statement and so we reiterate BUY and downgrade our EV/EBITA and P/E based target price to 120p from 200p.
